title: Letters: Bigger GST a Band-Aid solution for economic illness
text:
Don’t be complacent on income inequality

The AFR View ‘‘New generation of wealth to lead digital charge (October 25) claims there ‘‘has been no significant overall widening of income inequality in Australia over the past two or three decades’’.

The opening sentence of the 2018 report by those well-known communists at the Productivity Commission states that ‘‘over nearly three decades, inequality has risen’’. The only argument is about whether the increase is ‘‘significant’’.

The standard measure of income inequality compiled by the ABS – the Gini coefficient – rose from 0.30 to 0.33 over the past two decades. OECD data show this is the difference between inequality in Switzerland and in Russia.

Income inequality in Australia has not increased as much as it has in the United States but this is no reason for complacency. Economic growth over the past two decades has meant that in Australia even those on the lower incomes have seen, on average, some real increase. In a slowing economy this may not continue to be the case.

Dr John Hawkins

University of Canberra

Higher super rate would benefit us all

In ‘‘Albo enlists Keating for super fight’’ (October 26-27), Paul Keating is reported to have said ‘‘Superannuation has revolutionised Australia. It’s the greatest reform to capital markets in the history of the country.’’

Is it not true that the previous two years of trade surpluses have been aided by superannuation funds? Having invested internationally, they are now providing returns by way of cash inflows to the country.

It means somewhat less reliance on iron ore and coal and potentially having much greater impact in years to come.

Raising the superannuation contribution rate not only benefits individual superannuants, it benefits the entire country.

Elizabeth Wirtz

Cape Woolamai, Vic

Myer, analysts and investor information

Justice Jonathan Beach claims that Myer’s misleading of the market between September 11, 2014, and March 19, 2015 “... is likely to have had no or no material effect on the market price of [Myer] securities” because “... the hard-edged scepticism of the market analysts and market makers at the time of the contraventions had already deflated Mr Brookes’ inflated views” (‘‘Myer misled shareholders but still wins’’, October 24).

These “market analysts and market makers” obviously had the information, and acted on it. But where did they get this information from? Certainly not from a properly informed market. The laws governing market disclosure are designed so that all investors are protected by access to information.

Advertisement

Malcolm Cameron

Camberwell, Vic

‘Big stick’ could be applied elsewhere

The spectacle of Prime Minister Scott Morrison and Treasurer Josh Frydenberg berating the banks for not passing on the three Reserve Bank cash rate cuts is normal theatre.

But why stop at the banks? The ‘‘big stick’’ that was applied to energy providers could equally be applied to the oil companies gouging drivers. Or applied to milk prices to appease the dairy farmers and break up the supermarket duopoly.

Is one ineffective ‘‘fig leaf’’ sufficient to portray policy action for this ‘‘free market’’ government?

We could always have a few more inquiries, produce some more reports that are never released and hope everybody focuses on the cricket this summer.

Barry Cook

Soldiers Point, NSW

RBA funding banks: what would it cost?

So the Reserve Bank thought it was a good idea to fund the banks threatened by historically low interest rates (October 28).

Why was similar protection not offered to our car industry or to much of our manufacturing industry hit by extreme energy prices?

This policy doesn’t make any sense as it contradicts liberal ideology that all businesses should stand on their own.

How much would the RBA be prepared to fund and for how long? What would be the cost to the taxpayer?

Rodney Green

Burwood, Vic

AFP should raid Taylor

Will the AFP raid the office of Energy Minister Angus Taylor concerning a document used to mislead the public and Parliament?

Malcolm McDonald

Burwood, Vic
